Yes, absolutely! Art and literature continue to play a significant role in shaping contemporary politics and culture. For example, art has been used to spread awareness and advocate for social justice causes such as Black Lives Matter and the #MeToo movement. Street art and graffiti have also been used as a means of political expression and dissent in countries such as Hong Kong and Iran.

In literature, contemporary writers have explored new forms and themes that reflect the changing social and political landscape. Novels such as Margaret Atwood's "The Handmaid's Tale" and George Orwell's "1984" have inspired political activism and raised awareness about the dangers of authoritarianism.

There are also new forms of art and literature emerging that reflect the impact of technology and the internet on society, such as digital art and social media poetry. In addition, the role of storytelling in shaping our collective understanding of history and social issues cannot be overstated, as evidenced by the popularity of films such as "Black Panther" and television series such as "Game of Thrones."

In short, art and literature continue to be powerful tools for shaping public opinion and influencing social and political change in our modern world.
